questions.answer_description: 802.11n only supports open authentication or the use of WPAv2 with AES. From the output shown in this question, we can see that WPA/WPA2 using TKIP has been configured, not AES.

questions.answer_description: Clienlink is not enabled and should be in a mixed client environment. Many networks still support a mix of 802.11a/g and 802.11n clients. Because 802.11a/g clients (legacy clients) operate at lower data rates, the older clients can reduce the capacity of the entire network. Cisco's ClientLink technology can help solve problems related to adoption of 802.11n in mixed-client networks by ensuring that 802.11a/g clients operate at the best possible rates, especially when they are near cell boundaries.

choices.B: WLAN > QoS properties are incorrectly configured.
choices.F: Wireless > AP > 802.11 b/g/n > Network is incorrectly configured.
choices.A: WLAN > General properties are incorrectly configured.
choices.D: WLAN > Advanced properties are incorrectly configured.
choices.E: Wireless > AP > 802.11 b/g/n AP is incorrectly configured.
choices.C: WLAN > Security properties are incorrectly configured.

discussion.content:
The answer is correct, but for the wrong reason.
The problem is not because Clientlink is disabled, that will not prevent any users from connecting. Clientlink helps newer clients connect to better speeds when there are older clients on the same network.

The reason the clients cannot connect is because the data rates 1Mb/s, 2Mb/s and 5Mb/s have all been disabled. Legacy 802.11 clients only support 1Mb/s or 2Mb/s, so there is no link type enabled they can use.

Sorry the answer is correct.
But this is a tough one, because the patterns look so similar they could be either.
To complicate things, a single patch antenna will not make this pattern, it is made by a 4X4 array of patch antennas. The image used for the question is shown as a patch antenna here:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/wireless/aironet-antennas-accessories/prod_white_paper0900aecd806a1a3e.html

This question is not worded correctly.
The answers would be correct if changed to: "Disable all NON-OFDM Rates"
OFDM supports data rates of 48, 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, 6.

To disable all OFDM rates, you would need to disable 6, 9, 12 and 18.
That is four options when the question only calls for 3.

Fully agree with xtrattitude4u,
OFDM are 6,9,12,18,24,36,48,54.
Therefore C, D, F are the correct answers.

questions.question_text: An engineer has been asked to disable all OFDM rates in the wireless environment. What three rates should be disabled to fulfill this requirement? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
The question definition and answer are wrong.
Which option is the maximum power setting for an access point in any regulatory domain on a Cisco Wireless LAN Controller? 
A.5
B.8
C.1
D.10

So here, yes the correct answer is C. 1

questions.question_text: What is max power for an AP for all regulatory bodies?
